pinyin: chī bǎo le fàn chēng de

etymology.description: 吃(吃) (chī, "eat"), 饱(飽) (bǎo, "full"), 了(了) (le, "[modal particle indicating completed action]"), 饭(飯) (fàn, "meal; rice"), 撑(撐) (chēng, "support; prop up"), 的(的) (de, "[possessive particle whose function is to express possession, modification, or description]")
etymology.interpretation: The phrase 吃饱了饭撑的 (chī bǎo le fàn chēng de) is a colloquial expression implying that someone, having eaten a fulfilling meal, engages in unnecessary or frivolous activities for lack of anything better to do. It humorously suggests that one's over-satisfaction has led them to overextend into doing trivial or senseless things.
etymology.simplification: The simplified characters are 吃饱了饭撑的.

parts.english: [possessive particle whose function is to express possession, modification, or description]

examples.chinese: 他吃饱了饭撑的(他吃飽了飯撐的)，整天无所事事(整天無所事事)。
examples.pinyin: Tā chī bǎo le fàn chēng de, zhěng tiān wú suǒ shì shì.
examples.english: He has nothing better to do and spends his day idly.

examples.chinese: 朋友嘲笑他吃饱了饭撑的(朋友嘲笑他吃飽了飯撐的)，因为他没什么目标(因為他沒什麼目標)。
examples.pinyin: Péngyǒu cháoxiào tā chī bǎo le fàn chēng de, yīnwèi tā méi shénme mùbiāo.
examples.english: His friends mock him for having nothing better to do because he lacks ambition.
